newsitem.title: USA: Maine GOs sound investments says - AG Edwards.
newsitem.headline: Maine GOs sound investments says - AG Edwards.

text.p: Maine general obligation bonds and the state's moral obligation-backed debt remain sound investments for conservative accounts, A.G. Edwards & Sons analyst Patrick Early said in a recent report.

While Moody's Investors Service Inc is reviewing its current Aa rating on the state, Standard & Poor's Corp continues its AA-plus rating with a stable outlook as does Fitch Investors Service Inc which rates Maine at AA.

Maine will face challenges in its next biennium budget cycle to cut expenses, Early said. Tax cuts already enacted is expected to impact state revenues by about $325 million or 18 percent of general fund revenues budgeted for the fiscal year ending June 30.

"This will be a significant reduction which will require additional spending restraint, work force reductions and productivity initiatives," Early said, adding that while Maine has shown job growth and recovered almost all of the jobs lost since the 1989 recession, the new jobs are in lower-paying sectors.

While manufacturing employment has declined, it remains a vital component of the state's economy, Early said. Gov. Angus King has also made efforts to expand the state's share of jobs in the financial, high-tech and bio-tech sectors.
Noting Maine had been prone to annual cash deficits over recent years that has lead to short term borrowing, the state nonetheless posted a positive cash balance in fiscal 1996, the first since 1990.

"Maine has a low and manageable debt burden with no major capital projects planned," Early said. "Debt reduction has been imbedded in the state's plans for future issuance" at a level equal to no more than 90 percent of the principal retired in a given year.
He described the state's payment schedule on its debt as "aggressive."
